Award.AwardTitle: Building Capacity and Collaborations to Prepare Equity-minded STEM Teachers
Award.AbstractNarration: The project aims to serve the national need to recruit, support, and train STEM teachers in science education and equity practices. This training is locally critical as Illinois continues to experience teacher shortages in many STEM areas, while also seeking to increase representation of science teachers from underrepresented groups. Specifically, the project will seek to increase teachersâ€™ capacity to work with diverse student populations as well as improve the achievement of K-12 students in STEM subjects. To lay the foundation for achieving this goal, the project will partner with local high-need schools, minority-serving community colleges and local STEM organizations. The project intends to strengthen partnerships with several districts in and around Chicago, develop mentoring programs for pre-service and early-career STEM teachers, and refine curricula to smooth the pathway to the classroom for teacher candidates in several STEM disciplines. <br/><br/>This project at North Central College will include partnerships with Chicago Public Schools and J. Sterling Morton High School District 201. Project goals include: (a) strengthening science education collaboration within North Central College to develop and advertise clear pathways for students to double major in education and a science discipline; (b) expanding achievable pathways in science education for a diverse population of students transferring from community colleges; (c) collaborating with high-need local educational agencies to recruit high school students and, later, as sites for clinical placements of education candidates; (d) training candidates in use of equitable instructional strategies; and (f) supporting pre-service and early career STEM teachers through mentorship. In addition, the project will conduct surveys and semi-structured interviews to better determine needs and interests among individuals eligible to pursue science teacher licensure. Data will be analyzed by the team and independent external evaluators, and knowledge gained will be reported to all partners. The intellectual merit and broader impacts of this proposal are closely tied to the project's major aims of (a) establishing pathways designed to increase the number, quality, and diversity of licensed science educators in the Chicago area, and (b) initiating systems to improve the supports provided to candidates and new teachers to help increase their efficacy with all students and retain them in teaching. This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the persistence, retention, and effectiveness of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program Capacity Building grant carried out by North Central College (NCC) had four major goals: build and strengthen internal and external collaborations to support the training of secondary education STEM teachers, develop instructional materials to support teacher candidates in equitable instructional strategies, create a cycle of mentorship to support teacher candidates and beginning teachers, and conduct a needs assessment with relevant stakeholders.  

To make it possible for students to finish the programs in a 4-year timeframe, we redesigned our STEM/Education curricular pathways. Pathways were revised for Biology and Secondary Education double major, Chemistry and Secondary Education double major, and Physics and Secondary Education double major. A new pathway was developed for Environmental Science and Secondary Education double major and the teacher licensure program was approved through the Illinois State Board of Education. We communicated these new pathways with admissions and advising staff. To further strengthen STEM education collaborations within NCC, we also facilitated discussions amongst faculty related to preparing secondary education STEM teachers.  

In addition to internal collaborations, we also worked to build and strengthen external collaborations with local community colleges and high-needs LEAs. We carefully considered the curriculum of local community colleges to determine compatibility of the course offerings and degree requirements with transfer pathways into STEM education at NCC. We developed transfer pathways for chemistry/education and physics/education at Elgin Community College and are continuing discussions about future collaborations. We met with administrators from five local high-need districts to discuss needs for STEM teachers and what they would like to see from a partnership with NCC. Because of Streamwood High School?s (Elgin U-46) dedication to growing a more diverse STEM teacher pipeline and proximity and frequent path to Elgin Community College, we plan to collaborate for a Track 1 proposal. 

We developed three primary activities to support students in equitable instructional practices. First, we have created equity modules for STEM teacher candidates. Second, we have designed third-space learning opportunities for STEM teacher candidates to discuss equity through movie clubs. Third, we have created a professional development curriculum for field supervisors of STEM teacher candidates to support equitable instructional practices. We also designed a mentoring model, including topics for monthly seminars, agreement letters from STEM/education alumni willing to serve as mentors, a guide for alumni/mentee activities, and a timeline of support for scholars during their first three years of teaching. 

To assess the perceived needs of future STEM educators, we drew on the experiences and perspectives of high school students, community college students, NCC students, current STEM teachers who are NCC alumni, and current STEM teachers from our partner district. We collected survey data and interviewed a subset of participants. Initial results indicate the primary barriers as perceived by STEM educators for going in STEM education are cost of the degree, fear of STEM, and negative experiences with STEM. The top perceived needs are clear plans for a four-year program through licensure, and financial support. Students are interested in majoring in STEM/ed because they think the major is important, they value the major, and they think the major is useful. They are most interested in support in the form of a mentoring network throughout their career and in assurances of a job after graduation. 

The Noyce Capacity Building grant has allowed the grant team to build collaboration among college faculty, local schools, and community colleges. The grant team has developed STEM/education four-year plans and transfer plans to make STEM/education more accessible. With this groundwork, NCC is prepared to submit a Track 1 Scholarship and Stipend grant to prepare equity-minded STEM teachers.
